data.text: The TransAmerica Trail: Bike Touring Thru Grizzly Territory

For those of you who have done the TransAmerica Trail, did it ever feel sketchy going through Grizzly territory, especially since it’s a rural biking path? That’s the only portion of the route that kind of has me feeling a certain way (since I plan on doing it East to West in the Spring.)
Carry bear spray. It works. But honestly, I’d worry more about people than the grizzlies.
data.author: Mike Samsen

data.text: What this guy said ^^^^^^ Bear spray, if want something slightly smaller a bear banger could work too.
data.author: Corey Thomas

data.text: I carry bearspray here in Tennessee when hiking, but not necessarily for black bears, but like you’ve said; for sketchy people.
data.author: Matt Campbell

data.text: Does bear spray work on the bears as well, or only the people?
data.author: Matthew Signorini

data.text: LOL. Bear spray is designed specifically to deter bears. It actually can be harmful to humans. For humans, pepper spray is more appropriate.
data.author: Mike Samsen

data.text: It's not so much a path as highways. I did not feel sketchy but I was aware when I was in areas where extra caution is required.
data.author: Michael Viglianco

data.text: Bears aren’t a bother. They usually run when they see you
data.author: Ty Dawley

data.text: That path is well traveled and the bears are in the mountains during summer.
data.author: Samuel Lea

data.text: In the last decade, grizzlies have killed 8 people in the lower 48. Over that same time period, about 10,000 cyclists were struck and killed by cars. Just to let out the relative risk into perspective. Get a bell and don't keep food and toiletries near where you sleep.
data.author: Timothy Faust

data.text: Grizzlies aren't really a problem, even in Yellowstone. Stay in the campgrounds and you will be fine. The trail is all highway through there.
data.author: Curtis Bunton

data.text: Bears are extra-hungry in the spring after hibernating all winter. Don’t be breakfast.
data.author: Richard Mitchell

data.text: Well, I’m heading East to West, so it’ll be well in to Summer by the time I get in their territory lol
data.author: Matt Campbell

data.text: also the majority of our grizzly attacks are late fall. Coincidentally the same time as hunting season. They are going through hiberfasia, gorging themselves for their long nap. Most of the encounters are with hunters.
data.author: Curtis Bunton

data.text: People are not bear prey. That's a pretty ridiculous statement.
data.author: Daniel Ellsworth

data.text: You will be absolutely fine. I was being absurd. Bears are a non-issue except for the inattentive tourists driving cumbersome RVs gawking at wildlife and not seeing cyclists.
data.author: Richard Mitchell

data.text: Of course you are entirely correct. It was meant as a bit of silliness in this endless bear preoccupation. It is by and large bears who are at risk, not people. More people die of bee stings each year and herbivore cows are the most dangerous large mammals in North America.
data.author: Richard Mitchell

data.text: Did you see my note below?
data.author: Richard Mitchell

data.text: i hadn't. Thanks for pointing it out. Yes. The whole bear thing is totally over the edge. In Alaska where I lived most of my life probably more people got killed by moose. I can tell you I've been chased by moose a few times and never by a bear. Though I've had more than a few encounters. All were brown bears. They want nothing to do with people unless they feel forced into it. Black bears actually are more bothersome. But in a nuisance kind of way. In short as cyclists we've a lot more to worry about from people actions. Cars and etc.
data.author: Daniel Ellsworth

data.text: As I quipped the problem with bears is the tourists driving giant RVS so intent on gawking at wildlife they fail to see bicyclists with whom the need to share the road. In Canada it is the geese that get me nervous and by whom I’ve been chased.
data.author: Richard Mitchell

data.text: I grew up on a lake with swans and they can get a bit vicious.
data.author: Daniel Ellsworth

data.text: I recently rode parts of it in grizzly country during the spring (when bears are most active) and I never even saw a single bear. Probably worth carrying bear spray and a bell if you do the GDMBR, but not much point on the Transamerica.
data.author: Ben Grad

data.text: Seemed to not care about us unless I tried to eat the dandelions, too. Her cubs came up behind us and we stood in a group until she moved on. You’ll note she was tagged. Personally, there are a lot of wild animals on the trail - I’ve had to wait for buffalo, elk, elephants and moose to move along at their own pace. The mountain lion took off before I got there…..all of which could cause harm but very, very rarely do especially compared to how often we harm ourselves.
data.author: Jim Lee

data.text: This was the next day….ran after the 2nd cyclist came down the road and she had a clear escape route.
data.author: Jim Lee

data.text: Sketchy yes. Grizz country is very sketchy. Be aware and be smart. Follow recommended precautions in grizz country. They are no joke.
data.author: Robin Brodsky
